column1: believe-out-loud 95468454739 "2014-08-22 16:23:00 GMT" http://believe-out-loud.tumblr.com/post/95468454739/equality-michigan-responds-to-attacks-on "Our hearts are saddened by this sad news out of Michigan. We send our prayers out to our trans community and their allies.Â  equalitymi:  Statewide LGBT Anti-Violence and Advocacy Organizations Urges LGBT People to Be Extra Cautious in Palmer Park Area DETROIT â€“ Detroit Police are investigating three possibly related violent crimes near Palmer Park
column2: located along Woodward Avenue between 6 and 7 Mile in Detroit. Â At least two of the victims are transgender women
column4: whose gender identity is not yet public
column5: was killed in Palmer Park last Friday. In that case
column6: it is believed the victim may have been killerâ€™s partner
column7: and that after the murder took place
column9: crashed into another car and ran away on foot
column10: but a gun was left behind. The shooting on Sunday and another last week were not fatal
column11: but the victims were transgender. No one is in custody but police say they have a person of interest. Equality Michigan
column12: the statewide anti-violence and advocacy organization serving Michiganâ€™s lesbian
column17: supports victims of anti-transgender crime and tracks violence against transgender people throughout Michigan. The group has been helping law enforcement officials investigate the cases. Statement by Yvonne SiferdDirector of Victim Services
column18: Equality Michigan â€œWe are saddened to hear of the targeting of transgender people yet again in Michigan and that yet another life has ended too soon. We urge anyone with information about these shootings to contact the Detroit Police at 313-596-2260 or if you have information that you would like to report anonymously call Equality Michigan at 313-537-7000. We unequivocally offer our support to the victims and their families
column19: and stand with our trans sisters who experience violence at disproportionate and alarming rates. We hope that those responsible are swiftly apprehended and brought to justice.â€ â€œTransgender women are far too often victims of the most severe violence. Our most recent report through the National Coalition of Anti-Violence Programs
column24: Queer and HIV-Affected Communities in the United States in 2013
column26: the vast majority of anti-transgender incidents reported were committed against transgender women. Transgender women are twice as likely to experience discrimination
column27: 1.8 times more likely to experience harassment
column28: and 1.5 times more likely to experience threats and intimidation compared to overall survivors.Â Equality Michigan and the NCAVP denounce violence and seek to raise awareness of the violence faced far too often by LGBT people in Michigan and especially people in the transgender communities. We encourage members of the LGBT community to be extra cautious around Palmer Park until the those responsible are caught.â€ ### Equality Michigan has worked passionately for over 20 years to achieve full equality and respect for all people in Michigan regardless of sexual orientation
column29: gender identity or gender expression. For more information

column2: Rev. Kittredge Cherry compiles information on the â€œqueer sideâ€ of St. Francis:  When Francis (1181-1226) was a young man
column3: he had an unnamed male companion whom he dearly loved â€“ and who was written out of history after the first biography. Other Franciscan friars referred to Francis as â€œMotherâ€ during his lifetime. He encouraged his friars to be mothers to each other when in hermitage together
column4: and used other gender-bending metaphors to describe the spiritual life. He experienced a vision of an all-female Trinity
column5: who in turn saluted him as â€œLady Poverty
column6: â€ a title that he welcomed.Â   In another article on Jesus In Love
column7: Franciscan scholar Kevin Elphick reveals new information about St. Francisâ€™ earliest companion
column8: who he believes to beÂ Brother Elias of Cortona.Â  Image Credit:Â â€œThey Shelter in a Caveâ€ by JosÃ© Benlliure y Gil (1926)
